biogHists.text:
Congressman.

From the description of Reminiscences of Richard Walker Bolling : oral history, 1983. (Columbia University In the City of New York). WorldCat record id: 309721572

Richard Walker Bolling was born May 17, 1916. He served as a U.S. Congressman from the Fifth District of Missouri, 1949 to 1983. He died in Washington, D.C. on April 21, 1991.

From the description of Bolling, Richard Walker, 1916-1991 (U.S. National Archives and Records Administration). naId: 10569960

Richard Walker Bolling (1916-1991) was born in New York City and graduated from the University of the South with a B.A. (1937) and M.A. (1939). Residing in Kansas City, Missouri, Bolling represented Missouri’s fifth congressional district as a Democratic Congressman in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1949 to 1983.

Source: “Richard Walker Bolling.” Biographical Directory of the United States Congress. Accessed August 4, 2011. http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=B000605.

From the guide to the Richard Walker Bolling Collection 2011-208., undated, (Dolph Briscoe Center for American History, University of Texas at Austin)

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Sargent Shriver oral history interview, 1987.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Shriver discusses Gillis Long's political skills, his support for civil rights and its influence on his success in Louisiana politics, his work within the Democratic Party and on the House Rules Committee, his relationships with other representatives, especially Richard Bolling, and Long's voting patterns. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Louisiana State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.title: Congressional papers, 1910-1998, bulk 1946-1998.
resource.abstract: This collection contains correspondence, clippings, press releases, brochures, pamphlets, speeches, bumper stickers, transcripts, government reports and publications, maps, congressional documents, schedules, invitations, bills, whip polls, whip notices, and publications primarily generated and received within the context of Albert's service and leadership in the U.S. House of Representatives.

resource.title: Blair Moody Papers
resource.abstract: Detroit newspaperman and United States Senator from Michigan. Correspondence chiefly concerning his 1952 senatorial campaign and his newspaper work in the United States and abroad during World War II; scrapbooks of newspaper articles written by Moody and published for the most part in the and ; tape recordings of public affairs radio program; photographs and motion pictures of public affairs interview programs. Detroit News Barron's
resource.extent: 27.5 linear feet (in 29 boxes), 29 film reels, 60 phonograph records, 37 GB (online)

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers relating to Dierenfield's biography of Howard W. Smith[manuscript], 1978-1985.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The papers include correspondence with the University Press of Virginia, archivists and Southern historians responding to reference queries or critiquing the book, together with notes from interviews, and transcripts of interviews particulary with Smith's friends and congressional colleagues including Watkins M. Abbitt, Thomas G. Abernethy, Carl Albert, Dick Bolling, T.M. Carruthers, the Rt. Rev. Samuel B. Chilton, Luther H. Dudley, Carl Elliott, Sr., A. Sydney Herlong, Gordon Lewis, and Howard Worth Smith, Jr. A copy of Carl Albert's foreward for the book is also included. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Virginia</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Sydney Herlong, Gordon Lewis, and Howard Worth Smith, Jr. A copy of Carl Albert's foreward for the book is also included.

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Oral history interviews, 1975-1984.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Interviews conducted by Dierenfield for his biography of Howard Worth Smith. People interviewed include Thomas G. Abernethy, Watkins Abbitt, Carl Albert, Dick Bolling, Armistead Boothe, Albert V. Bryan, Carl Elliott, Francis B. Gouldman, Charles A. Halleck, A. Sydney Herlong, Gordon Lewis, W.R. Poage, George C. Rawlings, Bill Tuck and Kenneth T. Whitescarver, as well as family members and friends Violett Smith Tonahill, John W. Painter, Mrs. James M. Dyer and the Reverend Samuel B. Chilton. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Virginia</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Oral history interviews, 1975-1984.
resource.abstract: Interviews conducted by Dierenfield for his biography of Howard Worth Smith. People interviewed include Thomas G. Abernethy, Watkins Abbitt, Carl Albert, Dick Bolling, Armistead Boothe, Albert V. Bryan, Carl Elliott, Francis B. Gouldman, Charles A. Halleck, A. Sydney Herlong, Gordon Lewis, W.R. Poage, George C. Rawlings, Bill Tuck and Kenneth T. Whitescarver, as well as family members and friends Violett Smith Tonahill, John W. Painter, Mrs. James M. Dyer and the Reverend Samuel B. Chilton.
resource.displayEntry: Dierenfield, Bruce J., 1951-. Oral history interviews, 1975-1984.

                     </role>

                     <namePart>Richard Bolling for Congress Campaign Committee.</namePart>

                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1920-1967.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Correspondence, reports, memoranda, financial statements, publications, a scrapbook, and other papers, relating to personal affairs, to Evans's career as co-founder and president of the Crown Drug Company and as president of KCMO Broadcasting Company, his civic activities in the Kansas City area, and his activities as chairman of the Harry S. Truman Campaign Fund Committee in 1944 and as chairman of the Richard Bolling for Congress Campaign Committee in the elections of 1950-1962. Correspondents include Harry S. Truman. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Harry S Truman Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Truman Campaign Fund Committee in 1944 and as chairman of the Richard Bolling for Congress Campaign Committee in the elections of 1950-1962. Correspondents include Harry S. Truman.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:309721572</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-ZCU</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Bolling, Richard, 1916-1991.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Edwin, Ed,</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Reminiscences of Richard Walker Bolling : oral history, 1983.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Background and early education; Army duty in Pacific, 1941-1946, on General MacArthur's staff; vice chairman of American Veterans Committee, 1946-1947; election to United States House of Representatives, 1948; political problems of first term; functioning of the House of Representatives, 1948-1982: committee work on Banking, Joint Economic and Rules committees, civil rights; legislative strategy of Kennedy administration; impressions of Presidents Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson, and John F. Kennedy; Sam Rayburn and other political leaders. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Columbia University In the City of New York</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Reminiscences of Richard Walker Bolling : oral history, 1983.
resource.abstract: Background and early education; Army duty in Pacific, 1941-1946, on General MacArthur's staff; vice chairman of American Veterans Committee, 1946-1947; election to United States House of Representatives, 1948; political problems of first term; functioning of the House of Representatives, 1948-1982: committee work on Banking, Joint Economic and Rules committees, civil rights; legislative strategy of Kennedy administration; impressions of Presidents Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson, and John F. Kennedy; Sam Rayburn and other political leaders.
resource.extent: Miscellaneous papers relating to oral history.
resource.displayEntry: Bolling, Richard, 1916-1991. Reminiscences of Richard Walker Bolling : oral history, 1983.
